body:
These changes improve the project files, but do not fix it completely. There are more files to be removed and some files to be added.

I'd suggest removing visual studio solution completely, and use cmake to generate them when needed. They seem to be pretty unmaintained anyway.

@kainjow I've created WIP PR #2048, but didn't have time to fill all the tests out. Nevertheless, there are couple PR's in the queue that improve the server situation in Swift (from non-compilable to more or less working). It's hard to get the tests merged if the tested code does start at all. Would failing tests get merged unless they are committed as one bunch with all the other PR's?

There seems to be low interest in either using the server code or in upstreaming the required changes, otherwise this situation would not happen.

I've found a small improvement where the Javascript target actually depends on the target that copies the compiler into the source tree, not on the build of the compiler. This ensures that if the compiler is *not* built, it will still be copied.

If the CI is now successful, this should be ready for review / merge.
There seems to be an unrelated issue in https://travis-ci.org/github/apache/thrift/jobs/677163097. Should I re-trigger the builds and tests?
Re-triggered build with a rebase on latest master, to fix random error in Travis CI.
@dmaluka This is a nice changeset. To promote your change, maybe just re-trigger the build so that hopefully tests work? With 1 out of 2 builds I'm lucky and get all green lights :-)
:-( Another random error in the CI. Can this be merged anyways?
Re-triggered via force-pushing the same change again.

They seem unmaintained because some people started the CMake switch but never finished it. Hence we have two build systems to maintain and files that ought to be automatically generated and therefore shall not be maintained anymore manually (with the exact same reasoning that you brought up) to this day still are not generated and also nobody maintains them anymore.

So what's the status of CMake support? I had an impression that CMake is able to build the compiler and the c++ library at least (that's what I've used to compile thrift compiler on OS X and Windows (I didn't compile c++ lib).

I suppose MSVC files are third build system (autoconf/automake, cmake, msvc).

BTW. Should we move this discussion to the mailing list?
Thanks! The remaining ones are probably unrelated problems but could you do me the favour and force-push again to trigger CI?
Need this fix!

Thanks for the PR! Couple of things before this can be merged:

- Please open a Jira ticket and discuss why this change is needed. It's not obvious to me why we should preallocate pointer fields.
- Please add a test case.
- Please squash your commits and write a commit message that follows the [contribution guidelines](https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#github-pull-requests).

I'm going to close this now. After discussion on Jira, we can reopen if necessary.

Thanks for the PR @emmenlau!

I'm not familiar with Windows or MSVC but this is at least harmless for other platforms so if nobody objects, I'll go ahead and merge this in 24 hours.

Thanks for the PR @spwin! Can you please add a test case so this won't regress in the future?

The C++ library supports THeader, which is more or less transport agnostic and should be the preferred way of setting headers.

This PR on the other hand, effectively bypasses the thrift protocol. If you really think this needs to be in thrift, please open a Jira ticket as advised and discuss.
Travis errors seem transient, restarted the build.

Since the original issue is more than 2 years old without any solution, I'm happy to just disable this on Windows.

> Rebuilding docker image ubuntu-xenial

> > The command "if [[ `uname` == "Linux" ]]; then build/docker/refresh.sh; fi" failed and exited with 1 during .

Possibly you are right, but I've just seen a very similar error in an unrelated build. Could you pelase re-trigger Travis once to see if that helps? See also my related email to dev-list from today.

I've restarted it and it failed again, because there really is a bug :slightly_smiling_face: This:

```
echo "deb https://deb.nodesource.com/node_10.x xenial main" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list
```
should be
```
echo "deb https://deb.nodesource.com/node_10.x xenial main" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \
```
(note the `&& \` at the end)

Hi guys, I'm trying to find my way around here and eager for this PR.
I see the changes have been approved. Could anyone tell me what happens next?
@alexanderedge could you please rebase from master? The CI failures are unrelated but there have been some fixes on master and I'd like to see if we can get a green build before merging.

@kirviz: It is waiting for someone with commit rights to either merge this or complain :) In the mean time, if you can try this at home :) and report the results here (e.g. as a review), it may help the committers to decide. For that you need to checkout the source from this branch, build the compiler, somehow include the new library in your project and run tests/run the project.

> @alexanderedge could you please rebase from master? The CI failures are unrelated but there have been some fixes on master and I'd like to see if we can get a green build before merging.

Yes, I can do that 👍 

Unfortunately I'm no longer working on the project that uses Thrift but I'm happy to help get this PR merged.

> It is waiting for someone with commit rights to either merge this or complain :)

I'm not familiar with Swift but others in this PR seem to be, so I'd be happy to merge it :)

> Yes, I can do that :+1:  Unfortunately I'm no longer working on the project that uses Thrift but I'm happy to help get this PR merged.

Great, thanks for the PR! I'm sorry for the review delays and I'd like to get this merged as soon as we can.

Dammit, you are right! Thanks.

Slightly off-topic, I think the comments in the Dockerfile should really be changed. I've had good experience with adding comments in chains of ` && ` via echo. So instead of
```
# dotnet (core)
    curl https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc | gpg --dearmor > /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/microsoft.gpg && \
    echo "deb [arch=amd64] https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/microsoft-ubuntu-xenial-prod xenial main" > \
      /etc/apt/sources.list.d/dotnetdev.list && \

# node.js
    curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/gpgkey/nodesource.gpg.key | apt-key add - && \
    echo "deb https://deb.nodesource.com/node_10.x xenial main" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \

# ruby 2.4
    apt-add-repository ppa:brightbox/ruby-ng
```

I personally would highly prefer
```
    echo "Installing dotnet (core)" && \
    curl https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc | gpg --dearmor > /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/microsoft.gpg && \
    echo "deb [arch=amd64] https://packages.microsoft.com/repos/microsoft-ubuntu-xenial-prod xenial main" > \
      /etc/apt/sources.list.d/dotnetdev.list && \
    echo "Installing node.js" && \
    curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/gpgkey/nodesource.gpg.key | apt-key add - && \
    echo "deb https://deb.nodesource.com/node_10.x xenial main" | tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/nodesource.list && \
    echo "Installing ruby 2.4" && \
    apt-add-repository ppa:brightbox/ruby-ng
```
This does some part of documentation, remains visible in the execution, and most importantly it does not break the chain of ` && `-connections.
That's a great idea actually, please go ahead and change it.
Actually, the build is all green now, so I'm gonna go ahead and merge it. Thanks everyone!

Yes, I found the problem with ASAN and checked it with ASAN after solving it.

The problem of incomplete display of g_malloc can be solved by configuring this parameter.

export G_DEBUG=gc-friendly
export G_SLICE=always-malloc
export ASAN_OPTIONS=halt_on_error=1:detect_leaks=1:log_path=/home/ubuntu/asan:fast_unwind_on_malloc=0:log_exe_name=true

The problem with the CI is not easily fixed for me. The issue comes from the fact that the autotools build does not resolve the dependency between tests and the Thrift library in the same way as I encoded it in cmake. A solution would be to encode these inter-dependencies in Thrift.sln.

But sadly I'm not knowledgeable enough in Visual Studio or autotools to fix either of these. Can someone help? If not, I guess this PR will need to wait...
